keyTakeAways: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) has been without off-site power for four weeks, the longest blackout since the war began, forcing reliance on emergency diesel generators.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has confirmed that work is underway to restore power after the establishment of rare 'ceasefire zones' between Ukrainian and Russian forces.
Both Ukraine and Russia have accused each other of causing the blackout — Ukraine claims Russia intentionally cut the power supply to test reconnection; Russia blames Ukrainian shelling.
The ZNPP is under Russian control since the early days of the war and has lost connection to the grid 10 times since the conflict began.
Restoration of off-site power is critical for nuclear safety and security, with both sides engaging with the IAEA to facilitate repair efforts.
The Russian-controlled plant claimed that its defense ministry provided security guarantees to allow restoration work in areas under active shelling.
A previous Russian strike on the Slavutych energy substation two weeks prior caused a three-hour blackout at the former Chernobyl plant, raising regional radiation safety concerns.
Ukraine's energy ministry attributed the current crisis to Russian military aggression, occupation of the ZNPP, and systematic shelling of energy infrastructure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Work is underway to restore power to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant (ZNPP) in Ukraine, following the establishment of rare ceasefire zones between Ukrainian and Russian forces. The plant has been without off-site power for four weeks—its longest blackout since the war began—forcing it to rely on emergency diesel generators. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed that repair efforts have begun after negotiations with both sides, with IAEA Director Rafael Grossi stressing the importance of power restoration for nuclear safety. Ukraine accuses Russia of intentionally cutting power to test reconnection, while Russia blames Ukrainian shelling. Both sides claim to have played a key role in enabling the repair work, with Russia asserting that its defense ministry provided security guarantees. This incident follows a previous Russian strike on a Slavutych energy substation, which caused a blackout at the former Chernobyl site and raised regional radiation safety concerns. The situation underscores the risks of military aggression on critical energy and nuclear infrastructure, and highlights the fragile balance of ceasefire zones in a war zone.
title: Work underway to restore power at Ukrainian nuclear plant as UN announces rare local ‘ceasefire zones’
